p: During the German period, there was an important medical facility in Moloundou [ 122]. In the 1920s and early 1930s, Moloundou and Yokadouma had only dispensaries run by nurses [ 72]. In the neighboring AEF areas, only Ouesso and Nola had a doctor each until 1934, whereafter a third medical post, in Berberati, is mentioned in the reports [ 51]. In the 1920s and early 1930s, there were a few nurse-operated dispensaries in Souanké and Sembé (west of Ouesso) and in Berberati and Carnot (north of Nola). In 1931, a new one was set up in Gamboula, at the AEF-Cameroon border [ 51]. During these decades, segregation camps for HAT patients ( hypnoseries) existed in Ouesso and Nola (the latter since 1909). Leprosariums were set up in Nola and Berberati in the early 1930s. In addition to these facilities, missions provided some healthcare [ 50, 51, 72, 121]. In these facilities, the number of injections per patient in HAT, syphilis, and yaws treatments was probably higher than in rural villages.
